Fields.DialogueText: Hey, hasn't Ane-san been a bit more of a hardass lately?
She has seemed pretty strict recently. She's usually a bit more relaxed.
Still good about minding our off time, at least.
I wonder if it's because of her alleged relationship with Oyabun? Maybe there's tension.
That'd be bad. Nobody likes it when their parents are fighting.
Korrrraa! If you have time to be gossiping like old women, you've got time to be making yourself useful!
Gah! Ane-san!
Oyabun too!
Shut it, bakayarō! She told us not to call Kanchou that.
Moushiwake arimasen, Kanchou, Ane-san.
You better damn run! If I catch you, you'll be cleaning the goddamn engine room till I can eat off the deck! Korrraaa!
Kuso! Kanchou! Did you, uh... hear any of that?

Fields.MenuText: The part about us being a couple? Intriguing, though, really.
Apparently some of the crew think you have a stick up your ass recently.
I hear we're fighting. Were you going to tell me what we're fighting about?

Fields.DialogueText: You don't have to look that pleased with the idea.
If I do, I'm going to work it out and beat them with it. Damn gossips.
I suppose we could find something to fight about. Maybe work out the tension on the mats. Judo sound good? Aikido?
Hmmph. Acting like a bunch of punks instead of wolves.
No sense being too harsh on them as long as everything is up to standard or better.
*ALARM*
You're not wrong, Kanchou. Once we've blasted these hags, we're due for some tea and a talk.
Can't have the children thinking we're fighting, after all.
@BATTLE
You know, Ashigara, I've noticed some changes in the crew recently.
The foreign sailors are using more Japanese, just to start, and I've seen tattoos peeking past collars.
What's a sailor without an iron heart, a salty mind, and a tattooed body, Kanchou?
Besides, morale is doing well, so as long as the sailors are happy...
It's arrogance I'm worried about. You're confident, but they might misstep if they try to follow in your wake.
I think they'll be fine, Kanchou. They have you for an example, too.
Speaking of tattoos, do you have a tattoo or two?
Sure do, Kanchou. Why? Want to see?

Fields.MenuText: Yes. Very yes.

Fields.DialogueText: You can't just ask to see a back piece so easily!

Fields.MenuText: Wouldn't that just be someone painting on your hull?

Fields.DialogueText: Huh!? It's entirely different, Kanchou!

Fields.MenuText: I'll show you mine if you show me yours.

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe I'll take you up on that offer soon, Kanchou.
Anyway, it's good for morale. It's a mark of belonging, of brotherhood.
Even amongst the women?
For onna-musha, brotherhood is one of the rare privileges we get to enjoy that others do not.
I... Tch. Kanchou, I hate to interrupt, but we're about to be needed on the bridge.
Sensing an enemy fleet?
I can't decide if I hear them, smell them, or "feel" them first somehow. Disgusting sensation, though.
Well, let's drive them off for the sake of your health, eh?
@BATTLE
Come on! The quicker you bring her down, the quicker we can enjoy our kill!
@BATTLE
Hmm. That's not right. Sailors lounging on deck smoking... XO!
Yes, Captain?
I want those idiots on deck, not hanging around with their feet over the side.
Aye, Captain. But...
Kanchou, I let them do that. This is their home. They're to use rope to avoid a man overboard.

Fields.MenuText: I don't give a damn. It's dangerous.
Them being tied to the hull won't help if we go to battle stations on short notice.
I'm not sure I like this, but if you're confident...

Fields.DialogueText: Relax, Kanchou. We're taking precautions while letting them relax in their own way. We may die before sunset, after all.
They're good sailors. They know their business.
I am, Kanchou! These are my fine wolves, after all. They'll be okay.
It really is giving them a chance to relax a bit more. They love the sea. I can't blame them for that.
Mhmm. I'm still worried about a call to stations.
My fine wolves won't be caught on the deck when the call to battle comes.
See that they aren't. We're all counting on you.
Oi! Kanchou! Over here.
That's quite the wolfish grin on your face, Ashigara.
I've got some good news, Kanchou. Intelligence reports that my favorite prey is in the area.
Cowardice is back? I'm surprised she's willing to show her face.
Cowardly and stupid? Quite the combo.

Fields.MenuText: Keep your guard up. Cowards tend to be sneaky, too.

Fields.DialogueText: She won't get a knife between our ribs. You have my word.

Fields.MenuText: This whole thing would be easier if they'd just stay dead.

Fields.DialogueText: Hah! Ain't that the truth?

Fields.MenuText: I wonder why she's back? They always have a reason, even if we don't get it.

Fields.DialogueText: I doubt it matters that much. We find them. We sink them. End of story.
Hopefully the scout planes will get us a location soon and--
Kanchou! Ane-san! We've got Morganas in sight!
Get a bearing on that plane and set us a course! Helm, bring us to battle speed once we're a few miles out.
Fog on the horizon! Kuso! Incoming!
Hah! They can't hit accurately at that range!
Battle stations! Flank speed towards the enemy!
That's the ticket! She wants a sniper duel, but she's getting a brawl!
@BATTLE
Teme! Cowardice is back! How did she pop up again so quickly?
Damn, she outmaneuvered us! Battle stations!
@BATTLE
Chikushō! How did this happen?
Even light shells from naval-caliber guns can kill crewmates. Cowardice attacked at max range before we even turned to engage.
I know that! They got caught out on deck even as the alarm sounded.
... They were probably out smoking. They didn't make it to action stations.
Ane-san...
Corpsman! Over here! You hang on.
I... can't. I'll cut my pinky off later to make up for it. It's stopped hurting. I don't think that's a good sign.
Just stay conscious, damn you! I...
... She's gone limp. Where's that corpsman?
Ashigara... she's gone.
... I know. Damn it.

Fields.MenuText: Are you okay?
There's others we can be helping. We'll mourn later.
She did her duty. May she be received in the next life with honor.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm fine. It's not my guts spilled all over the deck.
You're right. Damn it, where are those corpsmen?
If her ancestors won't receive her properly, maybe she'll be reborn as the wolf she died as.
It really is always this close, isn't it? Just an inch or two's difference between life and death.
It's the warrior's lot.
So it is. Hmm. The corpsmen are here. I... need to go.
Hmm. I haven't seen her affected by death like that before.
I'll have to check on her later.
Kanchou! We could use some help over here!
I heard you cleared the lookouts out of this post on the mast.
I told them not to run their mouths about it, either.
They seemed worried about you. I'm worried too.
You don't need to be. It's nothing. Just... something about that sailor dying.
We've both had crew die under our command before.
I don't think I've held someone as they died before, though.

Fields.MenuText: I didn't see you at the service. Mourning is for the living in the end, and we must honor our dead.

Fields.DialogueText: You... you're right. Come with me to the shrine? We'll light some incense together.

Fields.MenuText: It does feel a bit different, especially if you were right next to that person when the attack hit.

Fields.DialogueText: On some level I'm right next to all of them when they're hit. Caught with my guard down no matter where I am.

Fields.MenuText: As you've said before, death is part and parcel of our service as bushi.

Fields.DialogueText: It is, but so is being very hard to kill. If one sells their life, one should sell it dearly.
I'm not sure what's gotten into me. I'm not even human. Yet here I am, smoking and contemplating.
In a way, I'd say you're the most human of us all.
I'm not cut out for this heavy thinking. Some Kami have insight into our nature. I'm not one of them.
They might be wrong, too. Lots of humans think they have insight into our nature.
Heh. A fair point. Honestly, seeing for myself how fragile life can be... it gave me some odd thoughts.
Like what?
Nothing. Or, well... I wondered what losing someone special to me might be like.
A life without loss is a life without love. Everything has to end, even if we die of old age.
Hmm. I suppose then that the question comes down to if one believes love is worth the pain.
I'd say it is for most people. Why? Got someone specific in mind?
What? No! Of course not!
The lady doth protest too much, methinks.
Enough of this. I... kuso. Kanchou! Look! On the horizon! Oni!
Blast. They really have a terrible sense of timing.
@BATTLE
Don't just glare at them! Blast them!
@BATTLE
You've got an odd look on your face. The cooks getting creative in the mess again?
Not especially, though damn you for reminding me of that... whatever that was.
What's on your mind, then? Or is there a problem with the ship?
Oi. Any problem with me is a problem with the ship, baka.
Nothing like that, though. Just thinking.
Does relying on others make you weak?

Fields.MenuText: Well, codependence to the point of being unable to do anything yourself is bad.
Not especially, least of all with people you have a close bond with.
Depends on how you mean, I guess. We have to rely on each other in combat, for example.

Fields.DialogueText: Right. Where's the limit on that, though? Kuso.
Well, there's that at least. I have tha... I mean, bonds are important!
Yeah, I didn't mean like that. Well. I did, but not... chikushō! Now I'm more confused than ever.
What brings this up, Ashigara? Are you having a problem with someone?
It's... none of your concern. I'll handle this.
Huh. She's definitely not her usual self. She was really bristling there.
I'll have to keep an eye on her.
Hmm... interesting.
Ashigara? You around here?
Kanchou! Don't sneak up on me like that.
I didn't know it was possible to sneak up on you. Doing some reading?
Ah. Yes. It's, uhm... a martial arts text. About training hard enough to fight in perfect sync with someone.
That sounds pretty interesting. Learn anything useful so far?
Oh, uh, yeah. All sorts of stuff. On another note, I caught a couple from the crew in a supply room.
Sometimes I'm not sure if our crew are professional sailors or teenagers.
Both, sometimes. Do you have an official policy on relationships like that?

Fields.MenuText: That type of thing can cause trouble, especially between disparate ranks.

Fields.DialogueText: What if they're around the same grade... or outside the chain of command?

Fields.MenuText: The INPF works on a slightly different drumbeat than a normal navy. If it becomes a problem, though...

Fields.DialogueText: How much trouble can that sort of thing cause, really?

Fields.MenuText: We might die tomorrow. May as well live while we can.

Fields.DialogueText: Sounding like a pack leader there, Kanchou. In the moment, taking life as it comes. A good point.
So what's the book about?
Oh. Right. A samurai took a wife from a clan famous for its onna-bugeisha, or women warriors.
Iron sharpens iron. They trained extensively together, sparring even with live blades.
A time came when the samurai's lord was attacked, and the samurai was caught at home with few retainers.
It was said that the attackers couldn't even get close to the couple, such was the fury of their blades.
They attacked and defended in perfect harmony, protecting each other while laying low their enemies.
That level of bond can't be truly trained, I suppose. Bit of a waste of time to read, honestly.
Sounds more like the plot of a romance novel than anything else.
Did it offer any decent training techniques for pairs, at least? Maybe we could adopt some for training the crew.
No! Er. No. Not really, but I'll see what I can do. Martial arts raise the spirit, at the very least.
Sounds like a plan. Let me know when you're ready. We can try them together.
I'll be watching you while we fight, Kanchou. Gotta figure out where to start.
@BATTLE
Smoke on the horizon! Looks like a convoy under attack!
Today we hunt, my wolves! Let's show those oni what happens when they muscle in on our turf.
*ALARM*
Bring us up to battle speed! All ships engage!
Get those boats into the water! We need to pick up survivors and get crews to help on ships that are still afloat.
Swim if you have to, damn it! There's kids in the water!
Cargo nets over the side!
Chikushō! If only we'd gotten here sooner. Damn Cowardice to Tenma's hottest hell.

Fields.MenuText: We can only do so much. We fight them wherever we find them, but there's a lot of ocean out here.
We got here. That's what matters in the end.
There's people who will live today because of our work. That's our comfort in times like these.

Fields.DialogueText: I know you're right. It's just so goddamn frustrating!
Yeah, but if we could have been faster... reconned sharper... something. Anything.
Small comfort for the dead, but you're right.
Come on. Let's organize some space below decks for survivors till we can reach a safe port.
On your best behavior, my fine wolves! We've got guests!
Break blankets out of stores and get the cooks working on something warm. We need to get the survivors dry and fed on the double.
Warmth and a full belly can cure a lot of ills. Another piece of pack wisdom.
It's about all we can offer. We don't have much in the way of amenities. You are my hungry wolf, after all.
Damn straight. Lean, fast, lethal, and yours. I--
Why'd she run off like that? Ashigara, wait up!
@BATTLE
Are you sure this is safe?
Yare yare, Kanchou. Didn't expect you to get so skittish about a little sparring.
It's easy to do when your opponent is a heavy cruiser.
Keep your shirt on. I'm not your opponent, remember?
This is from that manual about pairs fighting as one.
Still looks a lot like sparring, but all right.
It's easy. Just mirror my movements. I strike right, you block left, and so on.
Like... this?
Right. Now, let's speed up a bit. Start moving. Right, easy rotation.
Now you start striking, making the pattern a bit more complex. Your goal is reading my movements. Every twitch, every breath.

Fields.MenuText: What exactly is this supposed to do again?
This is more intense than I was expecting.
Hard to focus on your movements with you staring deep into my eyes like that.

Fields.DialogueText: Prep for the actual exercises. Each of us must know how the other moves.
I, ah... yeah. I see what you mean.
Fufu, you scared yet? Or is it something else about my eyes?
I hate to say it, but I don't think this will help the crew much.
You might be right. Do you want to stop?
... No. What's the next step?
*ALARM*
Kuso! Just when things were getting interesting! I'll rip that yōkai's throat out with my teeth for that!
Get to the bridge now, vow dismemberment later!
@BATTLE
Unbelievable. Where were they hiding?
*ALARM*
Wherever it was, they'll wish they'd stayed there!
@BATTLE
I don't like this.
Oi, Kanchou! I... huh. That's a serious look on your face. What's wrong?
We're being stalked.
Nani? Who? Who's got that special blend of stupidity and gall?
Not sure. Might be Murder, or just random Morgana transmissions.
She's a fool, then. We're well outside of her weight class.
We've intercepted a few random transmissions. Our names were heard among them.
Hmph. I had Murder pegged for more directness than mind games.

Fields.MenuText: It might not be an intentional broadcast. Their equipment isn't exactly standard.

Fields.DialogueText: True. They do look more like roving scrap heaps than proper warships.

Fields.MenuText: Calling us out certainly strikes us as Morgana-like.

Fields.DialogueText: Eh. As expected of the feisty ones. Murder's just a thug.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not worried about it regardless. The enemy is the enemy. We crush them.

Fields.DialogueText: Ryōkai! That's the spirit, Kanchou.
Still, your name... I wonder if that's a message to me.
Why would my name be a message to you?
Because she's coming for you, and she's going to hurt you to hurt me.
Making a lot of assumptions about our relationship, isn't she?
Any Kami worth her salt would be hurt if she failed to protect her kanchou.
That some Kami are more... intimate with their chosen would just make it hurt more.
Especially because most of us aren't quite used to having emotions the way humans do.
I've been wondering about that. Belles always seem to be at the extreme edges of emotion.
Imagine laughter, love, bloodlust... all for the first time. Every emotion is like that for us. For a while, at least.
For better or for worse, some of you never lose that emotional spectrum.
Gotta keep things interesting for the kanchou and the crew somehow.
With Belles around, I doubt anyone's in danger of boredom.
Not to worry, Kanchou. I'll keep you entertained personally.
Come on, get to your stations! Give 'em something mean to look at!
@BATTLE
You chased off some of the lookouts again.
Had to meditate. I can stand the watch just fine.
So you say. That's a serious look on your face, though. Something wrong?
Kanchou, what do you think happens to humans when they die?

Fields.MenuText: I can't rightly know. No one can. That's probably why it's scary.
I believe there's something that comes after this world. Something more.
Humans... everything with a soul, really... they're all reborn until they learn what they need to.

Fields.DialogueText: Yeah... darkness, the unknown. I can understand that on some level. Even if I'm not quite human... or mortal, even.
I wonder... if I'm good enough, brave enough... if I can earn that type of next life too.
Hmm. That even accounts for Kami. Seems frustrating... but if learning the lessons was easy, it wouldn't be important.
Why the dark thoughts today, Ashigara?
Just reflecting. There's a lot of dead since the start of the war.
So I prayed for peace for their souls, and considered what that peace might mean.
A worthy enough goal.
It hasn't settled my thoughts, unfortunately.
I have... new emotions. I'm not used to them. I need to calm the seas inside, somehow.
Can I ask you about this another time, Kanchou? I need to think more.
Any time, Ashigara. Make sure you're fully settled. Apparently other parts of the INPF are turning up the heat.
And there's no doubt the enemy will respond by fighting even more fiercely... like the cornered animals they are.
We're going to lose a lot more people before this is over.
We all are. The more landlocked nations only think the Morganas can't touch them, but their cold claws will gouge the whole world before this is through.
Then we just have to give it our all and protect them as much as we can.
I'm going to stay up here a bit longer. Smoke my kiseru, perhaps. Care to join me, Kanchou? Your company always makes me feel... warm.
All right. Can't say there's anywhere else I'd rather be at the moment.
Then that's enough navel gazing for me, too. This moment deserves to be lived properly.
I'd say I'll drink to that, but I... oh. You have a gourd of sake.
Of course. Come on, just a tipple to raise our spirits. No more than a mouthful.
Fine. You're a bad influence, you know?
So I'm influencing you? Weighing on your mind, perhaps?
Just a little. Wipe that smirk off your face and let's enjoy the quiet for a bit.
Aye-aye.
It's not often that Ashigara asks me to her quarters, even after performing sakizuke.
Good timing, Kanchou. Come on in. Tea?
Sure, I'll take a mug. What's with all the paper and ink?
Calligraphy practice, for one. Sort of.
Mostly I felt like writing some poetry.

Fields.MenuText: You? Writing poetry?
You know, for all your rough edges, you really are quite refined.
As expected of a proper samurai. I bet you prepared the tea properly, too.

Fields.DialogueText: It's not that crazy! I have all sorts of hobbies, you know.
Don't tell anyone. It'll ruin my rep.
Of course! It's a matter of pride and honor.
I write more than just death poetry too, I'll have you know.
I'll be honest. Even with our recent talk, you never struck me as the type.
I have been working on one, of course. It's for... someone. In case the worst happens.
A last message, to say some things I feel like I haven't.
That's no good, Ashigara.
Huh!? Why? You're saying you wouldn't read my... I mean, they wouldn't--
Not like that. I'm saying that whatever you need to say, you should say it in life.
That way you'll be at peace should the worst come to pass.
If it's something important, it'll only hurt that person more to find out after you're gone.
That's... yeah. That's a good point.
I don't like seeing your ears drooping like that. Come on. Where's the bold Ashigara?
Whatever you want to say, do you really need to worry about it this much?
I... no. Probably not. There's just... it's complicated.
Anyway, here's the poems I wanted to show you.
... Beautifully written. All about blades, the sea... interesting motifs.
According to the Shinto priests, Japan formed from drops of salt water off the blade of a divine spear.
A fitting metaphor for a nation with a strong warrior culture.
Very. I am a blade for my homeland, after all, cutting through the sea...
Right. I see where you're going with this.
*ALARM*
You'll have to show me more later!
@BATTLE
Drive them below, my wolves! These lousy scavengers can find prey elsewhere!
@BATTLE
Ship adrift! Looks like a cargo ship, Kanchou.
Helm, adjust our course. Bring us alongside so we can check for survivors.
There's no one alive on that ship. Look how it's moving... and there. Blood on the fo'c'sle.
Damn. that's quite a bit of blood now that I get my spyglass on it. No bodies.
Must be the work of that Funayūrei we just engaged. Injustice, maybe? She does like her spectacle.

Fields.MenuText: She likes spectacle where people can see her.
Not enough blood for full-on beheadings. Besides, Injustice likes to display the bodies.
It's a lot of blood, but not enough to account for a crew of a cargo ship of that size.

Fields.DialogueText: True. She does like to make her statements and show off. Damned circus act.
Right, not nearly grisly enough for her. But who, then?
You're right. That is odd. Maybe they left the cargo intact?
Chief, boarding party away. Find survivors and police up any supplies.
The dead don't need it, but we can still make use of it.
Leave any food unless it's sealed. It might be tainted.
Nothing like some healthy paranoia to warm the heart.
Right away, Kanchou, Ane-san.
Still. Picking the bones of the Morgana's kill?
Wolves shouldn't turn their noses up at good meat. The bodies don't need it. We do.
I'll make sure Chief shakes the boarding party down for personal effects, of course. No need to loot the dead, but the actual cargo will just go to waste otherwise.
That depends on what it is.
The markings suggest that it's a small, independent freighter. Might have all sorts of goodies for use or for barter.
All right, it sounds like you know what you're doing. I know you're not terribly greedy.
Trust me, Kanchou, I have everything under control. I'm going to seize every advantage I can get for my fine wolves.
Whatever I do is for the good of the fleet. That's a promise.
I'll hold you to that.
Damn it, where's Ashigara? I need her help to...
... Is someone crying?
Kami-sama, doshio? I can't. Without Nee-sama, I just...
Shh. She died doing her duty. You honor her sacrifice by doing yours.
Now, head back to your quarters. Meditate. Remember the good times with your sister... and if you wish to, come see me again.
Kami-sama... arigato gozaimasu.
No need to bow your head to me. We're family here.
You can come in now, Kanchou. She's gone.
Taking up eavesdropping, eh, Kanchou?
Unintentionally. Was that Petty Officer Tendo?
Hai. She got some bad news from Command. Her sister was killed in action in another theater.
That's unfortunate to hear. Seems like you did a good job comforting her.
People turn to the kami in times of need. I admit I'm not entirely comfortable with that role.
Kanchou, it hurt me to see how badly this loss hurt my sailor. I hurt when I lose my wolves... but not like that.
If attachment leads to that kind of suffering... why allow yourself to fall into it with someone? With anyone?

Fields.MenuText: That's a pretty heavy question.
I think the answer's fairly obvious.
It's something everyone needs to answer for themselves.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not asking it lightly, Kanchou.
Enlighten me, then.
What's your answer, then?
In the end, Ashigara, a life without loss is a life without love... and without that, you may as well just stop living.
The love for family, for a beloved pet, for a lover... All things must end.
It's something we don't want to face, but love has its time. Our lives are better for sharing it.
Seems like a trap. You either hurt in the short term or in the long.
If you walk alone - always alone - you hurt from start to finish. Even you have your sisters, our pack...
My relationship with my sisters isn't like you humans think of it. I'm not sure I could say we love each other like Tendo loves her sister.
I'm not sure I'm anywhere as close to my crew as Akane is to her kin, too. The distance...
... Is required by our roles as leaders. A senior captain once told me that to be captain is to be alone. For everyone's sake.
You're not alone, Kanchou. You have me.
I suppose being devoted to one's ship is a more literal affair these days.
*ALARM*
Speaking of beings who live without love...
A little exercise sounds like exactly what we need to lift our spirits. Come on, Kanchou!
@BATTLE
There's that fleet on the horizon now! Bring us about! Korrrra!
Bosun, all hands to action stations. Helm, flank speed as soon as we're secure.
@BATTLE
Just once I want to crush one of those foul piles of scrap and have it stick.
It's fairly frustrating to see them keep crawling back. Roaches of the sea...
Damn straight, roaches. Far too hardy and disgusting for their own good.
By the way, any progress with that sparring manual?
It's not really sparring. It's martial arts for t... no. Why do you ask?

Fields.MenuText: I want to see if you'll finally admit it's a romance novel.
Well, we haven't gotten a chance to hit the mats lately.
Oh, you know, just looking out for you. Taking an interest in your hobbies.

Fields.DialogueText: It's not! A romance novel, I mean. Really!
Oh! Right. Yes, of course. That. I, uh... that would be nice.
I saw that smirk, you bastard.
Anyway. I should have more of the techniques worked out soon.
I take it you're still willing to be my partner?
Of course. I wouldn't want to do something like that with anyone else.
Kanchou! You can't say things like that where people might hear!
Hear what? We're just talking about friendly martial arts training, is all.
Ooooh. You! Fine. You'd better be ready when the time comes!
Hmm hmmmm...
Ashigara humming to herself? This I've got to see.
Oh! Kanchou, good timing. Here, come take a look.
Painting with your calligraphy ink?
I'd say it's a time-honored tradition in Japan, but I have no idea if that's true.
I was working on a new poem and I just... felt like painting.
Calligraphy is a form of painting, after all. It's all about brush strokes. This is no different.
This really is impressive, Ashigara. Are you sure you haven't done this before?
Praise me more. I like it when you do that. No, though... doodles, maybe, but never painted.
This is Mount Ashigara from Sagami Bay. I left Mount Fuji out... it would kind of dominate the background.

Fields.MenuText: Have you ever been to Mount Ashigara? Or Sagami Bay, I suppose.

Fields.DialogueText: Many times. It's a lovely spot to cruise through. We should visit sometime, Kanchou.

Fields.MenuText: What's this bit here? Looks like ruins.

Fields.DialogueText: There's some ruins on the mountain. On every mountain in Japan, it seems. It's an old country, after all.

Fields.MenuText: You're a wolf of many talents.

Fields.DialogueText: Versatility keeps me sharp, Kanchou.
I should do this more often, I think. It's relaxing in a way poetry isn't.
How so?
With poetry I have word and character choice to consider. There's things to consider for painting, too, but it feels... less cerebral.
So you write with your mind and paint with your heart?
Ie. I write with my soul.
Say, I missed this... There's two people walking the trail on the mountain.
You're, uh... clearly seeing things, Kanchou.
No, it's there. You don't waste brush strokes in a minimalist style like this.
You really don't have to look that closely, you know!
Say, does one of the figures have a ta--
*ALARM*
Kanchou! Hurry! They need us on the bridge.
Right, right, coming!
@BATTLE
Steady as she goes, helm. Half ahead. Nobody's been through these waters in a bit.
Aye-aye, Captain. Half ahead.
It's quiet.
It's a little too quiet. There's nothing. No fish leaping. No birds. It's dead silent, save for the waves.
Ashigara? What is it?
Korra! Full reverse! Signal all ships. We're heading into a minefield!
You heard the lady!
Kuso!
Now what?
Clever bitches. It's a trap. They're moving to engage.
Right. Bring us about and get us moving. I want us clear of this minefield before they use it to pin us.
Let's teach them a lesson about cornered wolves.
@BATTLE
A moment, Ashigara?
Sure. Emperor Meiji's bones, that was close.
Too damn close. You really saved us.
I should have sensed those mines earlier.

Fields.MenuText: That's foolish. You're sharp, but you're not a soothsayer.

Fields.DialogueText: Then maybe I need to take up fortune telling.

Fields.MenuText: The escorts should have sensed them. It's not your job.

Fields.DialogueText: Protecting my crew is always my job.

Fields.MenuText: You seem... more tense than normal.

Fields.DialogueText: I... maybe. What's it to you?
I understand that was a close call, but what's wrong with you, Ashigara? You're looking pale.
I don't know. I just didn't like that situation, was all. We could have easily been killed.
If their ships had been in position for an IJN-style long lance shot...
They weren't. We reacted quickly enough to dodge the minefield. That's thanks to you.
I suppose you're right. If you'll excuse me a moment, Kanchou.
Was she... scared?
KOOORRAAA! SHINE'E!
I hope she's not training with a person. I can hear those blows from here.
Chikushō. Broke the damn dummy again. Guess I'll have to get one of the engineers to weld it back up.
Everything all right, Ashigara? I don't often see you hitting hard enough to dent steel.
Kanchou! You. Of course it's you.
I normally hold back. It's easier for the more human-like Kami. Some of the more... detached ones... have a harder time.
Ashigara, you've been acting odd recently. Is everything okay?
... Do you mind if I tell you something personal?

Fields.MenuText: I like to think our relationship is pretty intimate already.
Of course.
Why couldn't you? I mean, we talk about personal matters all the time.

Fields.DialogueText: I, uh... you have a point there.
Right. Well.
I... it's different. Or maybe it's not. Or something.
Kanchou... I was scared the last time we went into combat.
I noticed. I doubt anyone else did. Your grip was so tight on your katana your knuckles went white.
Of course you noticed. You're you. Why wouldn't you notice?
So why were you scared? It wasn't the enemy and it wasn't the situation. I know you better than that.
Remember our talk about loss?
Be hard to forget it.
I was scared of losing something for the first time. Scared of losing someone.
Pretty disgraceful for a servant of the Emperor.
It's just human nature. Try as you Belles might to avoid it, you are us. Born of us.
The better angels of our nature, as one of my fellows referred to you.
Angel, eh? Their Kami must be one of those softer types. Not a wild wolf like me.
It takes all kinds. I rather like my wild wolf. So what were you scared of losing?
You. I was scared of losing you.
... I need to be alone. I need to think.
Recently, when I'm with you, I feel... odd. My heart races like you're hunting me.
That being said... Kanchou, could we train again soon? I think I've got some exercises worked out from that manual.
Of course, Ashigara. You just let me know when.
Now. We start now.
Apparently so.
@BATTLE
I got your letter. Very formal. I thought we were training, not going out to a gala event.
Har har. It just... seemed appropriate. That's all.
Whatever you want to do. Let's get started.
Right. So the first form flows like this... back to back, then ducking under each other's guard like this.
Complicated. You'd really have to know your partner to fight like this.
Like I said, Kanchou. Two fighting as one.
If I'm honest, it's... how I want to fight with you.

Fields.MenuText: We're a pretty damn good team already.
That's got a lot of weight behind it. Are you...
Then let's train together until we can.

Fields.DialogueText: We are, but we can always be better. Know each other better.
... I'm sure. Whatever I'm saying. I'm sure.
Hai, Kanchou-dono.
I made a decision. You're part of it, so you deserve to know.
This training is part of it.
I'm scared of you. Of losing you. Of what you represent.
It makes me want to run back to my den and hide. Being alone, not having a deep bond... it's familiar, at least.
Running and hiding? That's never been your way before.
It won't be now. I don't run from my fear. I run towards it.
So get ready, Kanchou. I'm coming for you.
All right. I'll be here. When you're ready.
I don't know h--
*ALARM*
Someone just signed her own death warrant!
To be continued... That said, you don't look scared this time.
My heart is settled. My mind is settled. I have my kanchou by my side.
There's not any Funayūrei in any hell that can scare me now.
@BATTLE
Again? Teme...
What's wrong?
Tell you later, Kanchou. We've got hags to bag.
@BATTLE
There's a problem, Kanchou.
Hmm? What problem? What's going on? Do I need to get to the bridge?
*ALARM*
No, nothing so simple. We've got someone haunting our footsteps. I suspect she has been for a while.
I suspect Dismay's been following us around. Despair too, possibly. They've been piggybacking signals onto our radios.
Surely the scouts would have noticed.
Funayūrei don't always move in natural ways. With a sub playing radio relay, they could remain out of visual range.

Fields.MenuText: To what end?
You said they were piggybacking signals on our transmissions?
The Morganas love their games.

Fields.DialogueText: I think they're playing psychological warfare games.
At very low frequencies. I hear far better than humans and I can just barely detect them.
Nothing frustrates me more than that pack of bitches not coming out and fighting like real women.
I suspected something was up the other day after my talk with Petty Officer Tendo.
So I started keeping an ear out. Most of the crew's fine, but the ones who listen to the radios regularly...
They tend to be getting a bit more extreme, emotionally speaking. Subtle stuff, but more than enough to start sowing fear and doubt.
That seems incredibly subtle for the Morganas.
Despair and Dismay are subtle emotions, Kanchou. But once they grip your heart, they kill just as ruthlessly as the fiercest hate.
Right. I assume you have a plan now that you've cottoned on.
You know me so well. I'll need a little budget next time we make port.
Do I want to know what for?
It'll be a surprise. Just trust me. I promise that if one or both of those cows is stalking us, they'll hate it.
Korrrrra! I can't stand party crashers!
@BATTLE
Let's see... looks like everything's back to normal, more or less.
Sounds almost as noisy as a battle out on deck. What's going on our there, Ashigara?
Oh, it's a battle of a sort, Kanchou. This is that blow I promised to strike against Despair and Dismay.

Fields.MenuText: Just looks like a party to me.
If all warfare required this much sake, it'd be a jollier world.
I see. Fight them by improving morale.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, but who's attending the party? Everyone not on watch, that's who.
You're not wrong there, Kanchou.
Perceptive as always. As expected of you, Kanchou.
We're going to get everyone's spirits burning bright.
Then I'm going to return the favor for that minefield the other day.
You think it was Despair and Dismay?
If they can stalk behind us, they can damn well spread caltrops in front.
I'll bait the hook with a few radio reports. "Accidentally" broadcast in the clear, of course.
They'll indicate a fleetwide morale problem. Then I'll send out a coded transmission indicating we're steaming to port.
Using one of the older codes we're pretty sure the Funayūrei can read, of course.
Then we head for the spot I picked out for a honey of an ambush.
Nice. What if they bring in more support than we can handle?
I'm expecting they will. I've quietly put out feelers to other INPF groups in the area.
We should have friends picking off their other squadrons as they try to move to hit us.
After all, our pack is much larger than one ship or one fleet.
You're smiling like a hungry wolf again, Ashigara. Glad to see your spirits back up.
Just you wait till I hand you Despair's head on a platter, Kanchou. Then you'll really see me smiling.
Sihhhh-tsuuuu. Ahh. Now that's the good stuff. One of the boys found some good tobacco last port call.
Any particular reason you're smoking out the porthole in my office?
Just enjoying a quiet moment, Kanchou. Why? Want a puff or two?
No, I actually have work to do for now. I already spent my break sparring with you, remember?
Rain check, then. Maybe down in my quarters? Break out some good tea or something.

Fields.MenuText: Sounds good to me.
Let's see if we can scrounge some snacks too.
You seem pretty relaxed today.

Fields.DialogueText: That's the spirit, Kanchou.
Not to worry. I'll break out my secret stash.
I am, come to think of it.
I've been thinking about loss again. Life. Death.
Nothing in this world stays forever. Change, including death, is our only certainty.
Even for ships of steel and men and women with iron hearts.
But that's no reason to despair. It's a reason to embrace life fully. To live with passion and vigor.
We might die tomorrow. We might die today. Better to cherish the moments we get and die with no regrets.
And that leads to you smoking in my office.
Because I wanted to smoke. As for my choice in location? You're smart, Kanchou. You'll just have to guess why.
*ALARM*
Damn! They told me we'd hooked Dismay. So much for my quiet moment.
Just something else to make the Morganas pay for.
@BATTLE
It's time, Kanchou.
The other ringleader's stepping into the ring?
Just like we planned. They won't be able to maneuver freely... and they might just find our mines, too.
Right. Let's do it, then.
@BATTLE
That was satisfying. We really taught Despair the meaning of her name.
Turning the tables on someone when they think they've got a winning hand can do that.
That felt like one of our better fights, too.
Like we were blending together. I was implementing your orders pretty much as you were saying them.

Fields.MenuText: We did seem to be working together even better than normal.
I don't think you got hit in the head during the fight.
We have been doing that training.

Fields.DialogueText: Mhm. It was good.
Har har, joker. I'm being serious here.
Seems like it's finally paying off.
I want to keep getting to know you, Kanchou.
I want to keep fighting with you till we really do fight as one.
I am your sword. My body is your weapon. You need merely to lash out, and I shall strike down your foes.
More formal than what I was expecting, honestly.
I've already made my choice with you, Ashigara. We're a team. We'll see this fight through.
We have to. For the dead... and so others might live.
May my hands be stained, so that another's might not...
Sounds like part of a poem.
It is. I haven't finished it yet. Care to come help me?
I think I'd like that.
About time you turned up, Kanchou. I was just about to send a bosun to drag you down to my lair.
A lair, now, is it? Am I at your mercy?
I have you right where I want you. Here. Read it.
Blossom on a blade
Petals dancing on the edge
Severed with a slice
Let the cold edge fall to me
Perfect blossoms yet remain
Finally finished it, eh?
Finally. Well? What did you think? Not that I care, really.

Fields.MenuText: A common pulse for the profession at arms. Well done.
Makes me want to go see some cherry blossoms.
You're really asking the wrong person for informed opinions on poetry.

Fields.DialogueText: Wasn't trying to make it too obvious.
Heh... not the goal, but not a bad idea. Hanami, you, some decent sake. Sounds good.
Look, if I can manage to write poems, you can manage to read them!
Look. Thank you, Kanchou... for being here for me.
There's nowhere else I'd rather be. We're a pack, right?
Damn straight we are, and with the two of us leading it...
Well, I almost feel sorry for those oni hags.
Not sorry enough to spare them, of course.
Damn right. Those perfect blossoms won't preserve themselves.
Now, I might not have some cherry trees handy, but I do have some good sake.
And if you've got some time to kill, I think drinks with good company sounds perfect.
You're on. I can safely say this is the best way to spend my time right now.
Good. I'll grab some cushions. Kick back and relax. My den is your den, after all.
